doc.field: As of today, it's the euro for non-cash transactions

As of 1 January it's euro year - in Germany and 10 more EU-member countries. Federal government, Mr Santer, president of the EU-Commission and Mr Duisenberg, president of the European Central Bank, called this a historic moment. In the financial metropolis of Frankfurt/Main several thousand people celebrated the introduction of the euro, a currency that will be used exclusively for non-cash transactions, for the time being. As of tomorrow, however, cheques, debit- as well as credit-cards may be made out in euro. Financial instruments made out in national currencies will stay in circulation for another 3 years. One euro is worth almost 1.96 German marks.
Mr Genscher emphasises importance of introduction of euro

Former Foreign Minister Genscher called the introduction of the euro a big wish come true. On radio Deutschlandfunk the former FDP-politician said that in this day and age of globalisation a common stable currency would be extremely important for Europe. At the same time Mr Genscher emphasised that the euro would do a world of good for the unification of member states.
Bankers change over to euro

Several thousand staff of European banks did not have a New Year's Eve party. They had to convert computer systems, as trading in shares and bonds will be in euro only as of Monday. The Dresdner Bank, for example, will have to cope with 9000 modifications to their banking software, at a cost of 250 million marks. Yesterday the EU ministers of finance and economics pegged the exchange rates of the euro. Now one euro is worth almost 1.96 German marks.
Germany chairs EU-Commission

As of today Germany will chair the European Council, for the next 6 months. The most important goals are, according to Chancellor Schroeder, reaching an agreement on the subscriptions to the EU common treasury (some are net-takers, others net-payers), the reform of European agriculture and regional policies as well as the planned European covenant for employment. Fighting unemployment is on top of Germany's list of priorities. There has to be a European covenant for employment, that's what 15 member states had agreed on during their recent summit-meeting in Vienna. That will be one of the items in the chair's 'very easy' basket. The planned EU reforms, however, will be a bigger problem. The 15 member states want to reach an agreement on this issue during a planned special summit meeting in March. The EU has to become ready and prepared for new memberships by Eastern European countries.
New Year's Eve revelling features numerous accidents and brawls

There have been numerous accidents, fires and brawls during this New Year's Eve's revelling. In Leipzig some 50 rioters set up barricades in the streets and battled with police. In the Upper Palatinate an intoxicated arms buff shot at his girlfriend with a crossbow and threatened 10 other persons. He finally was arrested, after he had broken a leg. In the Hochsauerland district a 30-year old man sustained life-threatening injuries after fiddling with gunpowder. Now the whole house is about to collapse, following the explosion in the cellar. All the same, police were full of praise for this year's mainly peaceful end-of-year revelling. People had been disciplined while having a ball.
DAG on their goals for covenant for employment

The German Employees' Union (DAG) is looking at a target of reducing unemployment by 300,000 once the covenant for employment gets under way. Head of the DAG Issen said, work had also to be spread more fairly. He was cautiously optimistic as far as the upcoming talks were concerned.
Mr Brie criticises PDS as lacking substance

Mr Brie, member of the executive of the PDS party, criticised his own party. In spite of the success at the federal election and having become a partner in the coalition governing the state of Mecklenburg-Western Pomerania he thought that there were substantial shortcomings as far as contents and strategies were concerned, when interviewed by the newspaper BERLINER ZEITUNG. The party especially was unable to live up to its manifesto's stipulation, namely that they would be left of the SPD. The PDS would be a world-champion with words, but lacked the substance to back them.
CSU wants to cap numbers of immigrants for family-reunions

The CSU party wants to cut immigration for family-reunion purposes drastically, according to a remit that is expected to be passed next week at the close-doors meeting in Upper Bavaria's Wildbad Kreuth. The remit proposes to cap the number of spouses/family members, similar to what is already happening in Austria. Austria has capped immigration of foreigners' dependents at 1000 persons/year.
Tomorrow hostages released in Yemen will fly to Germany

The four German hostages released in Yemen will arrive in Frankfurt/Main tomorrow morning. Two of them said, when interviewed on TV RTL, that their kidnappers had treated them according to the circumstances. However, shots had been fired once while they had been on their way, and that had been the most terrible moments. Today 9 British and 1 Australian tourists that had been freed by a military commando, flew out from Sanaa to Paris.
Less ethnic German refugees entering the country
Last year the number of ethnic German refugees returning to Germany dropped, reaching 103,000, which was 30,000 less than in 1997. Most of them left the former Soviet Union to come to Germany.
Summons to be posted by email, too

In Bavaria the courts of law are to use the Internet to speed up trials and cut costs. Verdicts, proposals and summons may then get posted using electronic mail instead of letters, according to Bavaria's minister of justice Sauter. Currently Bavaria was spearheading a working-group comprising federal and state officials who were looking at the required procedural changes.
Mr Schmidt wins New Year's skijumping competition
Martin Schmidt from Furtwangen won the traditional New Year's skijumping competition in Garmisch-Partenkirchen, the second event out of four. Mr Schmidt had already won the opening one at Oberstorf.
From the editors' desk

As of 1 January 1999 the exchange rates of the euro to most of the European currencies are set in stone, and will not fluctuate at all any more. That's why we will skip them in the future. We will, however, quote other exchange rates and economic indicators.
